He was a rebellious type of father, but he had a strong rebellious period, so when I was in the fifth grade, we fought every day, and my mother left the house.
That's how it was in my family.
So you are allowed to talk about such things?
Not at all, not at all.
We are very close, so there were times in the past, but....
Generally, girls and mothers are very clear about whether or not they will see each other, aren't they?
Yes, that's right.
We are good friends now.
My hometown is Okayama, but I have relatives in Kobe, and I used to visit them during summer and winter vacations.
I took the train to their house, and that was the only time I ever took the train.
So I had my mother take me to the station, and when I was in elementary school, I cried every time I had to say goodbye to my mother.
I went to Kobe, lived there for about a month, and cried again when I saw my relatives outside the train window on the way back to Okayama.
It was not so much that I went to a distant city, but rather that when I entered the ticket gate, I had to put in a child fare ticket, because I was a child.
The ticket made a beeping sound, and since I was a rather tall child, I was always suspected by the station staff.
I was always suspected by the station staff because I was a very tall child. I remember it well.
In Yokohama, there was Aki-Karen, wasn't there?
There was a Christmas market on Christmas Eve with one of the members, Hikaru Morita, so we went there together.
We went there together. We went there privately.
The old streets and buildings are still there, and it is a town that is suitable for filming.
That is why I have often filmed in Yokohama since I was young.
So I have the impression that Yokohama is that kind of town.
It is a picturesque town.
There are many picturesque places in Yokohama.
Yes, there are.
When you go back to Osaka, do you ever go through a tunnel in Shiga Prefecture and suddenly there is snow on the ground?
Yes, there is. Suddenly there is a snow zone.
I like that. It's like the world changes in an instant.
When I was little, I had a bento box shaped like a bullet train, and I used to enjoy eating it every time I got on the bullet train. I was sure to eat it.

Yes, it is. It was an ekiben for children, but I really liked it because it was delicious and looked cool.
